docs.lead_paragraph: ON a short list of the richest places in the United States, Nassau County and its exclusive villages virtually always rank near the top. Even in less expensive communities, the average household income is reported to approach $70,000 a year. Now an arbitrator's award that pushes the pay of police officers to historic highs assures that officers in the Nassau County Police Department will earn salaries to match the wealth, making them aristocrats among police forces.

headline.main: Police Wage Award Used Suffolk Scale, Rising Over 20%

docs.abstract: Officials in Nassau County, NY, estimate that arbitrator award made 10 months ago will result in average annual salary for police officers of about $100,000 within next three years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HUMAN genes hold a wealth of information that physicians hope will help them avert illnesses that may be passed on from one generation to the next. Yet the information, still a trickle but about to arrive in deluges, is so powerful that it will need to be handled with care. A foretaste of its power was offered by the recent report of a genetic change, or mutation, that has been found to double an individual's lifetime risk of colon cancer; the mutation occurs in 6 percent of Ashkenazi Jews. Those who test positive for the gene can periodically have colonoscopies, in which a physician examines the colon and removes the slow-growing polyps from which colon cancer originates. The procedure is thought likely to reduce the risk of colon cancer from significant to near zero.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Testing Genes to Save a Life Without Costing You a Job

docs.abstract: Potential problems with discrimination arising from genetic testing discussed in light of recent discovery of test for genetic mutation that increases risk of colon cancer among Ashkenazi Jews; testing for this or other genetic predisposition could pose problems for people applying for jobs or health insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: MONUMENTAL ART Patrick McCaughey, director of the Yale Center for British Art, calls one of the current exhibitors, John Martin (1789-1854), ''the Cecil B. de Mille of the 19th century.'' A painter who eschewed anything smaller than monumental, either in size or subject, Martin created some of his era's most striking works on religious and cataclysmic themes, mostly drawn from the Bible.
docs.abstract: Weekly guide to cultural events in Connecticut (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bonni Ellen Zwickel, a daughter of Harriet and Meyer Zwickel of Grasmere, Staten Island, was married last evening to David Andrew Bleustein, a son of Brenda and Jeffrey Bleustein of Milwaukee. Rabbi Thomas Weiner performed the ceremony at Windows on the World in New York. Mrs. Bleustein, 32, is a vice president of equity research at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York. She graduated from Baruch University and received an M.B.A. degree from New York University. Her father retired as a cook at Creamland Dairy, a restaurant in Brooklyn. Her mother is a special fraud investigator at Group Health Inc., an insurance company in New York

docs.lead_paragraph: If you are unimpressed with the plans that Governor Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey have offered to lower auto insurance rates in New Jersey, there are seven other gubernatorial candidates with something to say about the issue. They got a chance last week to outline their thoughts on auto insurance and other issues at a forum at Middlesex County Community College. With the exception of Governor Whitman, all of the gubernatorial candidates, including Mr. McGreevey, showed up.

headline.main: Hearing From the Seven Who Are Seldom Heard

docs.abstract: Jennifer Preston column on less emphasis on auto insurance rates as issue in New Jersey gubernatorial race (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Jiang Zemin opened China's 15th Communist Party Congress today by embracing a program of bold economic reform for the nation's ailing state-owned industries while deferring any significant change in the nation's political system. At the congress, a gathering of more than 2,000 delegates intended to approve leaders and policy for the coming five years, Mr. Jiang presided as the unquestioned successor to Deng Xiaoping, who died in February.

headline.main: China's Leader Announces Sell-Off of State Enterprises

docs.lead_paragraph: The Prudential Insurance Company of America plans to squeeze $250 million to $500 million in annual savings from the company's big, money-losing health insurance unit, Prudential executives said yesterday. They said the savings would be made by cutting layers of managers and tightening controls on medical services. Steven J. Shulman, the millionaire managed care entrepreneur who recently took over as president of the unit, Prudential Health Care, said the first cuts would be made in the next six months. He said the number of jobs to be dropped was still undetermined. Wall Street analysts estimated that 2,000 to 3,000 positions would go.

headline.main: Big Cutbacks Being Planned At Health Unit Of Prudential

docs.lead_paragraph: Six years after the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company became the largest American insurance company ever to collapse, the company has been revived and is expected to announce on Monday that it is for sale. No price has been established, but investment bankers estimate that the company could bring as much as $1.5 billion.

headline.main: Life Insurer, In Comeback, Is Set for Sale

docs.abstract: Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Co, six years after it became largest American insurance company ever to collapse, has been revived, and is expected to announce that it is for sale; investment bankers estimate that company could bring as much as $1.5 billion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Built a century ago as one of the first skyscrapers in downtown Manhattan, the former office building at 71 Broadway began leasing this week as the financial district's newest luxury rental and the latest response to the city's tight housing market. Once occupied by a string of companies, including onetime owner U.S. Steel, the white granite neo-classical structure now contains 237 mostly studio to two-bedroom apartments. The 22-story landmark runs from Broadway to Trinity Place along Rector Street, just south of Trinity Church and courtyard.

headline.main: Residential Real Estate; At 100, Skyscraper Becomes Housing
